commands.message: Initializes a new Git repository in the current directory
Creates a copy of a remote Git repository on your local machine
Stages changes for commit. You can use git add . to stage all changes.
Records staged changes into the Git history with a descriptive message.
Shows the status of your working directory, including changes to be committed.
Displays a log of all commits, showing commit hashes, authors, dates, and commit messages.
Lists all local branches. The current branch is highlighted with an asterisk
Switches to a different branch or commit.
Fetches changes from a remote repository and merges them into the current branch.
Pushes your local commits to a remote repository.
Merges changes from one branch into the current branch.
Reapplies your changes on top of another branch, creating a linear history.
Temporarily saves changes that are not ready to be committed.
Unstages files or resets the current branch to a specific commit
Lists remote repositories linked to your local repository.
Deletes a local branch.
Sets your Git username globally
Adds a new remote repository.
Applies a specific commit to your current branch.
Shows who made each change to a file and when.
